channel.title: Darren Eggenschwiler B.Eng. Video Producer | Tech Wizard | Cinematographer
channel.description: Darren Eggenschwiler B.Eng. Video Producer | Tech Wizard | Cinematographer

item.title: Blackmagic Cinema Cameras Have Just Been Upgraded
item.description:
Blackmagic Cinema Cameras Have Just Been Upgraded

Blackmagic Design have really nailed this one out of the park. The latest firmware (v1.8) for the BMC upgrades it in to an all new level. The most important change for me has been the super improved anti-aliasing moire reduction function of the prores debayer. (huh?)

item.title: Blackmagic Cinema Camera First Impressions
item.description:
Blackmagic Cinema Camera First Impressions

Wow. This camera is an absolute joy to use. It's essentially a lens, sensor and solid state drive. No frills, nothing fancy, just a solid 1.6kg block of metal which records exactly what's in front of it. Perfect. After filming for a few hours on the afternoon we received it, I discovered that it is also totally unforgiving.

item.title: Letus AnamorphX on the Blackmagic Cinema Camera
item.description:
Letus AnamorphX on the Blackmagic Cinema Camera

A week or so ago we ordered a Letus AnamorphX 1.33x anamorphic adapter. It arrived with five hours to spare before the Glasgow 48 hour film project. Phew! That was a nail biter. First off I wanted to show the squeeze factor, by filming a circular plate, and overlaying a perfect circle.

item.title: Blackmagic Cinema Camera First Footage
item.description:
Blackmagic Cinema Camera First Footage

Today we received a Seagate Goflex Thunderbolt adapter. Seagate Thunderbolt Sata Adapter This allows us to slap an SSD from the Blackmagic Cinema Camera straight into our iMac. Which is a lot quicker than what we had previously been doing, ... Continue reading →

item.title: Blackmagic Cinema Camera Is Coming To Production Attic
item.description:
Blackmagic Cinema Camera Is Coming To Production Attic

Tomorrow is the day I have waited eight months for. On Monday we are expecting the delivery of our very own Blackmagic Cinema Camera. I have a new understanding of the expression "early adopter". Committing to a purchase two months ... Continue reading →

item.title: Build Your Own Chinaball for Cinematic Lighting
item.description:
Build Your Own Chinaball for Cinematic Lighting

The first time I ever saw a Chinaball on a set was whilst watching the extra features on the Indiana Jones and the Crystal Skull DVD. I've found that exact moment on youtube, here it is: behind the scenes It's just a tiny glimpse, but ever since then it's been sitting in the back of my mind.

item.title: Better Lighting for Film Makers with FIPEL Technology
item.description:
Better Lighting for Film Makers with FIPEL Technology

Field Induced Polymer Electro-Luminenscence or FIPEL technology, is something film makers and video production crew could be using within the next year to create better looking images more safely and efficiently. It's been around for a decade or so, but recently some brilliant scientists (Dr. David L.

item.title: Lighting CRI and CT
item.description:
Lighting CRI and CT

So the main problem is that the big movie cats often use giant lighting fixtures with 18,000 Watts of power driving them, blasted through giant diffusion silks. Us film kittens can't do that because it would cost more monies than are currently available to us.

item.title: Make Your Own DCP
item.description:
Make Your Own DCP

The other day I succeeded in constructing my first ever DCP. It was a moment of great joy - the realisation of a dream - and I owe it all to free software from both commercial and open source software developers. If you don't know what a DCP is, then don't worry, neither did I a few weeks ago.

item.title: Dual System Audio Syncing with Chirp
item.description:
Dual System Audio Syncing with Chirp

I had a wonderful thought yesterday whilst listening to a podcast with Joe Rogan and Andreas Antonopoulos. They were speaking about Chirp. Chirp is a service which can encode any piece of data into a 20 tone audio clip which can be decoded by any Chirp client to link to the original data.
